flow.context: Liz Bernthal is VP Vacation Rentals at Dunes Properties, running their Charleston Coast Vacations brand — about 183 beach rentals across Folly Beach, Isle of Palms, Wild Dunes, Sullivan's Island, and Kiawah. Critical ops fact: they outsource ALL cleaning and maintenance to third-party vendors, so quality control is entirely a vendor handoff problem — and they run on TrackHS as their PMS. Trustpilot is 2.1 out of 5 with recurring guest complaints about condition and cleanliness, and the company just appointed a new COO with an explicit mandate around operational excellence. Sam's strongest hooks: RapidEye plugs directly into Track, and we already work with East Coast PM companies running a similar outsourced model.

gatekeeper_open.label: GATEKEEPER — SLIDE BY
gatekeeper_open.say: Hey — could you get me through to Liz? It's Sam.
gatekeeper_open.note: Don't pitch. Don't explain. Just a name and a request. Sound like you belong.

branches.label: Asks who you are / what it's about

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — ADD CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah — I work with a few other vacation rental managers in the Charleston area. Would you mind letting her know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Still not pitching. Just enough context to sound relevant, not enough to trigger a screening reflex.

branches.label: She's not available / take a message

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Totally understand — we help a couple other property management companies in the area with their turnover inspection workflows. I sent her a note the other day. Would you mind just giving her a heads up that Sam Parks with RapidEye called?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: This is your last push. If they still won't connect you, leave a message and try again another day.

gatekeeper_voicemail.label: VOICEMAIL
gatekeeper_voicemail.say: Hey Liz — it's Sam Parks with RapidEye. I work with a few other vacation rental managers in the Charleston market on their inspection workflows — specifically that gap between when third-party cleaners finish a unit and when your team actually knows it's guest-ready. I'll try you again tomorrow, but feel free to reach me first — it's [your number]. Talk soon.
gatekeeper_voicemail.note: Keep it under 20 seconds. One specific pain point, no pitch. Call back tomorrow at a different time.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Liz — I work with a few other vacation rental managers in the Charleston beach market, and your name kept coming up. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around at all?
opener.note: Smile. Relaxed pace. Sound like you're calling someone you were told to call. Pause after the question — let her answer.

branches.label: What is this about? / Are you selling something?

opener_heard_yes.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF YOU
opener_heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well we'd normally be working with someone in your shoes. What'd you hear?
opener_heard_yes.note: Let her talk. Whatever she says, use it to transition into discovery or pain. Don't correct — just steer.

branches.label: Describes what they heard / asks questions
Vague / not sure where they heard it

opener_heard_no.label: HAVEN'T HEARD — TRANSITION
opener_heard_no.say: Ha — guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call is —
opener_heard_no.note: Say this with a grin, then flow directly into the pain trigger. No pause here — keep the momentum.

opener_bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
opener_bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow morning? Or is later this week better?
opener_bad_timing.note: Don't push. Get a specific callback time. If she gives one, lock it in and hang up quickly.

branches.label: Gives a time / agrees to callback
Go ahead, you have a minute

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION — ASK FOR 30 SECONDS
permission_fallback.say: Yeah totally — I mean it is a cold call, I'll be upfront with you. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out? And you can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit.
permission_fallback.note: Acknowledging it's a cold call disarms the resistance. Most people give you 30 seconds. If they do, you MUST deliver the pain trigger concisely.

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED — SPLIT
permission_rejected.say: Totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and it's just not interesting?
permission_rejected.note: This gives her an easy out that still gives you info. 'Horrible time' reopens the door to a callback. 'Not interesting' lets you exit gracefully or probe.

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER
pain_trigger.say: I've been working with another PM company in a pretty similar setup to yours — about the same size portfolio, all outsourced cleaning crews, running on Track. And the thing their VP kept running into was this gap between when their third-party cleaners mark a unit done and when anyone on her team actually knows it's guest-ready. Their cleaners would send over photos after a turn, but with a hundred-eighty-something units turning, nobody had time to actually review every set before four o'clock check-in. Stuff slipped through — a stain on a sofa, a broken blind, a missing set of towels. And the first thing she hears about it is a guest complaint. Or worse, it ends up in a review. Does any of that sound familiar, or have you guys figured out a way around it?
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE after the question. This is the most important silence in the call. Let her fill it. The more detail she shares, the warmer she is. Do not speak first.

branches.label: Yes / that happens / tells their version
We have a process for that / we handle it
Not really our problem / not interested

pain_resonates.label: PAIN RESONATES — THEY FEEL IT
pain_resonates.say: Yeah — that's exactly what I keep hearing. So out of curiosity, when a cleaner finishes a turn right now, what does that handoff actually look like for your team? Like do they send photos into Track, or is it more texts and emails?
pain_resonates.note: She's warm. STOP pitching. Ask questions. Let her describe her world. The more she talks about her process, the more she'll see the gaps herself.

branches.label: Describes their process / talks about gaps
Asks what RapidEye does / how you'd fix it
Mentions specific pain (reviews, owner complaints, staff burnout)

pain_neutral.label: PAIN NEUTRAL — NUDGE WITH SPECIFICS
pain_neutral.say: Yeah — and honestly the thing that made it urgent for them wasn't even the big stuff. It was the cumulative effect. One missed issue is whatever. But when you're coordinating outsourced vendors across Folly, IOP, Wild Dunes — tight same-day turns — it compounds. Their area directors were spending half their day putting out fires instead of managing the portfolio. Is that at all what your directors are dealing with?
pain_neutral.note: Name their actual sub-markets to show you know their world. Referencing area directors maps to Mark Malone and Fran Cote's roles without being creepy.

discovery_inspection_process.label: DISCOVERY — INSPECTION PROCESS
discovery_inspection_process.say: That's really helpful. And when your team does spot something in those photos — like damage or a maintenance issue — how does that get routed? Does it go through Track, or is it more of a phone call to the vendor?
discovery_inspection_process.note: You're mapping their workflow. Listen for: manual photo review, text/email chains, lack of standardization, reliance on cleaner judgment. Each gap is a thread you pull in the demo.

discovery_vendor_pain.label: DISCOVERY — VENDOR COORDINATION PAIN
discovery_vendor_pain.say: Yeah, that's the thing about outsourced cleaning — you're only as good as the handoff. And your team's stuck in the middle between what the cleaner says is done and what the guest actually walks into. How much of your team's time would you say goes into just triaging those mismatches?
discovery_vendor_pain.note: This is where the conversation gets real. If she quantifies the pain — time, headcount, complaints per week — that's gold for the demo. Take notes.

review_pressure_pivot.label: REVIEW / REPUTATION PRESSURE
review_pressure_pivot.say: Yeah — and that's the part that compounds, right? One guest with a dirty unit is a phone call. But when it hits a review, now it's affecting bookings. And new owners looking at your program are reading those too. Is that something you guys have been actively trying to get ahead of?
review_pressure_pivot.note: Trustpilot is 2.1 out of 5 — she likely knows. Do NOT quote it. Let her bring it up or acknowledge the pressure. If she gets defensive, soften: 'Every PM company I talk to deals with this.'

branches.label: Yes, it's a priority / shares what they're doing

leadership_transition_thread.label: LEADERSHIP TRANSITION — NEW COO
leadership_transition_thread.say: Oh interesting — I actually saw you guys brought on a new COO recently with a mandate around operational efficiency. Is that driving some of these conversations internally? What I'm seeing with other companies going through that kind of transition is they're using it as a chance to lock in better systems before the next peak season.
leadership_transition_thread.note: Layne Kipp was appointed COO March 2025 focused on operational excellence. If Liz confirms it's driving change, you're aligning RapidEye with an internal initiative — powerful positioning.

branches.label: Mentions Layne or other leadership by name

solution_cta.label: SOLUTION + CTA
solution_cta.say: So here's the short version — we built an AI that plugs directly into Track and automatically analyzes every photo your cleaners are already taking after a turn. It flags damage, missing items, staging issues — before the guest checks in. No workflow change for your cleaners, no extra steps for your team. Would you be open to taking a look when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue?
solution_cta.note: One breath. Say 'Track' by name — removes the 'does it work with our system' objection instantly. The CTA is low-friction: just a look, not a commitment.

branches.label: Yeah, I'd be open to that
We already have something for that
I'm not the right person for this

solution_track_detail.label: TRACK INTEGRATION DETAIL
solution_track_detail.say: Yeah so that's actually the reason I reached out to you guys specifically — you're on Track, and we plug directly into it. So the photos your cleaners are already uploading after a turn get analyzed automatically. Our AI flags anything off — damage, missing items, staging that doesn't match — and it shows up as an alert before the guest checks in. Your team doesn't change anything they're doing today. Would you be open to seeing what that looks like with your actual units?
solution_track_detail.note: TrackHS integration is your strongest hook with Dunes. It kills the 'this sounds like more work' objection. If she asks technical questions, don't over-explain — save it for the demo.

branches.label: I'd need to loop in someone else
Not looking to add tools right now

warm_discovery.label: WARM DISCOVERY
warm_discovery.say: That's great to hear. So I don't want to waste your time going over stuff that's not relevant — what does your inspection process look like right now after a cleaner finishes a turn? Is there a formal check before the guest arrives, or is it more of a spot-check system?
warm_discovery.note: She's warm. Your only job is to ask questions and listen. The more she talks, the more invested she gets. Take notes for the demo and follow-up.

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: I totally get it. I should've assumed you'd be all set — otherwise you probably would've reached out yourself.
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first. Don't argue. The pause after this line is where she'll either soften or hold firm. Wait for her response before continuing.

objection_split_interest.label: SPLIT — NOT INTERESTED
objection_split_interest.say: Totally fair. And just so nobody from my team cold calls you again — is it more that this just isn't a problem you're focused on right now, or is it more that you hate cold calls and I caught you at the worst possible time?
objection_split_interest.note: Multiple choice, not a debate. Let her pick. If it's timing, you get a callback. If it's the problem, offer the test drive.

branches.label: It's the cold call / bad timing

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — WE HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with a hundred-eighty-plus units and outsourced vendors, you'd have to have something in place. I'd be shocked if you didn't.
objection_have_process.note: Validate. Do not challenge their process. The agree step lowers their guard. Pause, then split if she holds firm.

objection_split_process.label: SPLIT — HAVE A PROCESS
objection_split_process.say: Totally respect that. Honestly just so I'm not wasting your time — is it that your current process is catching everything and you're happy with it, or is it more that switching or adding anything right now would just be a headache?
objection_split_process.note: Nobody's process catches everything. If she picks 'headache,' the door is open to the test drive. If she picks 'we're happy,' offer the test drive as a benchmark — not a replacement.

branches.label: We're happy with what we have

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET / NOT NOW
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Nowadays it's harder to keep a tool, let alone buy something new. Especially with everything shifting on the leadership side — I'm sure budgets are under a microscope right now.
objection_no_budget.note: Casually reference the leadership transition. Shows you know their world and validates her constraint. Don't push budget — pivot to the split.

objection_split_budget.label: SPLIT — BUDGET
objection_split_budget.say: Just so I know — is it that budget for this cycle is completely locked, or is it more that anything you try to buy right now puts you through the ringer with approvals?
objection_split_budget.note: Both answers lead to the test drive pitch. The point is to understand her buying process, not overcome the objection.

branches.label: Budget is locked / can't spend right now

test_drive_pitch.label: TEST DRIVE — SELL THE LOOK
test_drive_pitch.say: Look, you're probably not buying anything from a cold call today, and I totally respect that. But here's what I've found — when budget does free up or peak season hits, the people who move fastest are the ones who already know what's on their list. If nothing else, I could show you what other PM companies running outsourced cleaning on Track are doing with their turnover photos. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends. Would you be open to a quick look?
test_drive_pitch.note: This is your last real shot. 'Other PM companies on Track' is the hook — she'll want to know what her competitors are doing. If she says yes, book it NOW.

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Awesome. I've got next week pulled up — how does Tuesday afternoon look? Say around two o'clock your time?
book_meeting.note: Pick a specific day and time. Don't ask 'when works for you.' If she counters with another time, take it immediately. Send the invite while still on the phone.

branches.label: Actually, just send me an email

meeting_pin_down.label: PIN DOWN THE MEETING
meeting_pin_down.say: No worries — is later in the week better? I've got Thursday morning open too. I'll send the invite right now so it's locked in and off both our plates.
meeting_pin_down.note: Give one more specific option. If she's still waffling, pivot to email as a fallback.

meeting_booked.label: MEETING BOOKED — WRAP UP
meeting_booked.say: Perfect — I'll get that invite over to you right now. Really appreciate you taking my call, Liz. Talk to you then.
meeting_booked.note: STOP SELLING. The meeting is booked. Say thank you and hang up. Every additional word is a chance for her to talk herself out of it.

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email.say: Totally fair — I'll send something over today. One quick question so it's actually useful and not just another generic pitch — what would be most relevant for you? Is it more the Track integration side, or more seeing what the AI actually catches on a real turnover?
send_email.note: Accept the email request. The question tailors the follow-up AND keeps her engaged for 10 more seconds. Include a specific meeting time in the email.

send_email_tailored.label: EMAIL CONFIRMED — WRAP UP
send_email_tailored.say: Got it — I'll put something together and shoot it over this afternoon. I'll include a couple times for next week in case you want to take a closer look. Thanks for the time, Liz — talk soon.
send_email_tailored.note: Send the email within the hour. Include: (1) one line referencing what she said on the call, (2) a relevant example, (3) two specific time slots. Follow up in 3 days if no response.

referral_ask.label: REFERRAL — WRONG PERSON
referral_ask.say: Oh totally — I appreciate you telling me that. Who on your team would typically own something like this? Like who's the person dealing with the day-to-day turnover inspection side?
referral_ask.note: She might point to Mark Malone (Folly Beach director), Fran Cote (IOP/Wild Dunes director), or Layne Kipp (COO). Get the name and ask if you can use hers.

referral_try_harder.label: REFERRAL — TRY HARDER
referral_try_harder.say: No worries — would it be one of your area directors? Like whoever runs the Folly Beach or Isle of Palms side? If I can get a name I'll put something tailored together so it actually lands and doesn't feel like a random cold email.
referral_try_harder.note: Naming area directors shows you know their org without being weird. If she gives a name, great. If not, don't push.

branches.label: Gives a name or confirms a role

referral_name.label: GOT A REFERRAL
referral_name.say: Perfect — I really appreciate that. Would it be cool if I mentioned you pointed me their way? That way it doesn't feel totally out of the blue for them.
referral_name.note: Getting permission to name-drop Liz turns a cold call into a warm intro. If she says yes, lead with 'Liz Bernthal suggested I reach out' on the next call.

referral_wrap.label: REFERRAL — WRAP UP
referral_wrap.say: Really appreciate it, Liz. Thanks for the time — hope you have a good rest of your day.
referral_wrap.note: Log the referral name immediately. Call them within 24 hours while the context is fresh.

end_callback.label: CALLBACK SCHEDULED
end_callback.say: Done — I'll try you then. Appreciate it, Liz.
end_callback.note: Write down the exact callback time. Set a reminder. When you call back, open with: 'Hey Liz, it's Sam Parks — you told me to try you back today. Got a minute?'

end_graceful.label: GRACEFUL EXIT
end_graceful.say: Totally understand. If anything changes, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks, RapidEye. Appreciate your time, Liz.
end_graceful.note: Don't burn the bridge. Send a brief follow-up email — one line, no pitch, just 'nice chatting, here's my info.' Re-approach in 3-6 months.
